text: this is a land with flows with beer it
takes it very seriously in 1516 the law
decreed that Brewers could only use a
few pure ingredients in some countries
they put rice in beer in Germany that's
fair Borton now the German Brewers
Association wants the United Nations to
recognize this law as a world treasure
and put it on the UNESCO World Heritage
List we are proud of of this culture we
are proud of this art of producing
brewing beer now with only four
ingredients so five thousand different
German beers brewed another purity law
is a good thing to carry out in the
world this small brewery noid cellar was
founded by monks 400 years ago when the
present owners put extra sugar in the
beer so breaking the German purity law
officialdom clamped down the brewery
nearly closed only a 10-year court
battle kept it open they argue here that
innovation and imagination is the way to
get the new customers the industry
really needs on average every German
drinks about two liters of beer every
week that's about four pints very high
on the international league table but
you know what they're drinking less of
it Germans are turning away from beer to
try to win back sales some smaller
breweries make non-standard brews like
English ales which German law says can't
be called beer they look across the
border to a land with great beer but
without German legal constraints we
don't need to look very far then we find
Belgium which has got a great beer
culture and they produce beers made with
spices made with fruits which wouldn't
be allowed in Germany the ancient beer
purity law may be a national treasure
but is it now holding German brewing
back a subject to be debated over a
glass of foaming ale stephen evans BBC
News Berlin
